review_title: Good or Bad Depends on the Business Group
job_title: Product Engineer in South San Francisco, CA
pros: Big reputable company. Nice to have on resume
cons:
The company is steering away from digital products. As a result, there are rounds and rounds of layoffs happening in the digital groups. No job security.
As people are being let go, the remaining employees are juggling more works left by employees who are leaving. Work load is huge. When you are burned out, they will just put you in the next round of layoff.
To be fair people in the analog groups are doing ok.

review_title: Rewarding and educational to learn new concepts
pros: Freedom to do your work and not excessive management interference.  Management team at the local level and next level are focused on the real challenges that impact your work.
cons: Join a group that has future potential impact.   Do not under estimated the power of communication with team and leadership.

pros: Great people and ethical culture. Texas is also an awesome place for lifestyle and has a vibrant technology industry.
cons: too conservative in terms of how they approach going after big opportunities and creating new parts for customers. need more aggressive and creative edge to win out in the marketplace.

pros:
You can develop your professionalism and communication because of regular interaction with stakeholders worldwide
Work-life balance. The company has recreational facilities - basketball court, fitness gym, etc that you can use during your break time or outside your shift
Generally, friendly and humble people in the workplace
Benefits - profit share, rice allowance, medical, insurance, dental, etc
cons:
Politics everywhere
Below average compensation (provincial rate)
Late night meetings if your counterparts / stakeholders are onshore

pros: Company has many different groups for career changes, great pay and benefits, global company great from business side and interactions. Tech company fast pace, go go  go very exciting. Work in a wide variety of products and industries. See and learn lots of great new technologies. Very supportive of females and minorities in all levels of the company.
cons: You will work many hours. Always seems there is something more that needs to be done. Plus global means most our your nights will be conference calls.

pros: The people at Texas Instruments are easy to get along with and upper management make efforts to reach out to lower-level employees.  No one works past 5pm.
cons: There could be more room for advancement and a lot of the work is boring.  It's hard to get passionate about their products and services.

pros:
TI shows concern over the career growth of interns and invest heavily into that. On my floor alone, there were at least three weekly classes held by full-time employees to help interns immerse themselves in the semiconductor industry.
I had a real project of which I could see the immediate impact and benefit to the product line and company. It was relatively well-organized and meaningful.
cons: In my role, there was not much room for side projects where I could experience the work of other roles.

pros:
1. Great atmosphere, lot of learning in a short time
2. Managers and mentors are quite friendly and extremely helpful
3. Clear picture about the role being assigned to you
4. Work-life balance
5. Texins, badminton and other recreational activities
6. Flexible work timings
cons:
1. Analog is given highest importance and ecalations which is not so present in Digital domain here.
2. nothing more as far as i suppose

review_title: Great people, great products but a tough business to be in.
pros:
Great people and no shortage of interesting challenges . 
Very active in all kinds of community activities.
Serious about protecting the environment.
cons:
It's a tough and demanding business and balancing work/life for many is a challenge.
However that's pretty standard in the industry so fixing it could hurt T.I.'s profitability.

review_title: For an innovation company, it's surprising how resistant some departments are to change
pros:
Relatively stable company
Decent pay and benefits
Opportunity to work with others worldwide
On the forefront of technology
Fair amount of flexibility, work/life balance is encouraged (in many areas)
cons:
Very conservative culture
Many employees have spent many years, even their whole careers here, and can be resistant to doing things and thinking differently
Operates very lean
Structure can be confusing

review_title: Great place to work if the business is nice and growing.
pros: Nice place to work. Great work life balance
cons: IF you are in a group that has diminishing returns better to look elsewhere as TI is not know to hang on to their employees or relocate to other groups. It will be an enmasse exit.

pros: Great place to work with work/life balance.  I worked there for 8 1/2 years and loved what I did.  I learned a lot and gained additional education paid for by TI.  Take advantage of all the various resources available to employees.
cons: Very political and competitive environment.  Opportunities to move up were slim and unlikely.   It is all abut who you know and not your skill.

review_title: Great experience, amazing people, great work-life balance
pros: You get to work on great technology projects with amazingly talented people. You get to learn a lot and explore the field of electronics.
cons:
While there's a lot of flexibility in terms of choosing your expertise, it's very difficult to move through verticals.
Also, there's this communication gap between business managers and subordinates due to which the latter are not able to relate their work to the bigger business strategy.

review_title: Company Focus on Analog and Embedded Beginning to Pay Off
pros: Tremendous focus and alignment.  When TI is focussed and aligned there is nothing it cannot accomplish.  Operational excellence is a key enabler.  Excellent place to learn and contribute early in career.
cons: Office politics just like any large company.  Very large company so helpful to work for a strong leader.  Mentorship is important.

pros: Profit Sharing. Used to be a great company to work in, specially in fab engineering role.
cons:
Work/life balance is getting worse every year. Management is very conservative on spending money on right things.
Salary increment is less.

pros: Flexibility, responsibility at an early stage, low politics, good learning curve which helps for your career and recognition for doing good work
cons: Changes happening very frequently which might be a challenge for some people to adopt, if you could keep up with the changes then a good company to work for and you can have long career here

job_title: Electrical Engineering in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Huge company - great job security.

Good CEO and direction.

Very ethical

Great work-life balance
cons:
Lots of bureaucracy. Kind of bloated.

Working at TI requires a lot of TI-related knowledge. Feels like one needs just as much technical knowledge of circuits as experience using TI tools.

Don't really get the feeling that you're working on the next great thing. Just making slightly better parts to keep up with the market.

pros: This is a strong, growing company which offers excellent compensation packages to it's employees. I found management to be fair and hardworking. Strong management-employee relations. A good place to start your career.
cons: Could increase benefits, as health care premiums continue to rise while benefits go down. Also, need to upgrade internal computer systems, working off last generation mainframes.

review_title: Future for OMAP business is unclear, expecting company to cut down heavily on new investments
job_title: Program Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Strong analog portfolio
Many opportunities to move internally to different business units
Competitive salary
(at least so far) very supportive customer base
cons:
Immature management (middle level)
On OMAP side, unclear vision from company leadership
Bleak outlook for embedded processing in general
Losing the customer base

review_title: Overall good company with some good ideas, but some poor managers
pros:
Great benefits
Some good ideas
Diverse product portfolio
Very fair work/life balance for the most part
cons:
Some clearly misguided market attempts
Some managers clearly rose through the ranks through brown-nosing and not competence
Training can be harder to come by than in similar companies
Can be a bit stodgy when it comes to seizing new markets and innovation

review_title: Not a decent place to work anymore
pros:
Flexible working hour
Nice and friendly coworkers
Used to be a good technical company, focus and reward technical development, 10 years ago.
cons:
Too many reorgs, top managements are changing mind daily.
Not rewarding talent nor contribution, cut people like throwing away old shoes, sucks.
Quality is no longer a concern to this company, how to finish thing in a cheaper way is more important nowadays.

review_title: Overall a great place to make a career if you started many years ago, now, not so much.
job_title: Technical Sales Representative in Boston, MA
pros: Pay and benefits are great, and opportunities are numerous and the products are industry leaders so it makes selling easy.
cons: Be careful as you become an older worker and be sure to stay relevant as there is a tendency to be pushed out, if you're not.

review_title: Texas Instruments is a very good company to work for.
pros: TI has a very diverse in their hiring.  They offer employees and contractors many perks and amenities.  The work atmosphere is friendly and casual.  They provide many opportunities for job advancement.
cons: Due to the nature of the business, it is either feast or famine.  Layoffs are always looming and you don't have the feeling of job stability.  The compensation and retirement packages are not always as generous as they should be.

pros:
1. The projects given are relevant to the work going on in the team
2. One gets first hand experience on industry related design standards
3. It is the best place to start work in the electronics field
cons:
The NDA restrictions make it difficult to access relevant information easily. 
One has to work hard towards getting the same. 
However, its justified at their end to place these restrictions.

job_title: Senior Product Test Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros: Good benefits package. One of the more stable semiconductor companies with good reputation. The company is quick to identify any losing business, so I would say good vision.
cons:
Deadlock and feeling stuck with the job and company due to the location. Dallas has no opportunity other than TI for semiconductors.
Company policies slightly on the conservative side with regards to flexible work schedule, maternity leave.
No sick leave given to employees, when you are sick the day off goes from your vacation days.

pros: Plenty of interesting challenges and priority to having appropriate work-life balance. Profit sharing bonus has been great past few years. Managers do care and try to help you develop in your role.
cons: Many positions are understaffed so there is risk of being overworked. Pay is fair but not quite a plus outside the heavily taxed bonus.

pros: good benefits, great training ground
cons: little respect for experience; you are asked to build a strong succession plan but once you pass 40, the company will replace you with someone you trained who has half your experience.

review_title: Poor pay for the amount of work
job_title: Verification Design Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros: Vacation Policy is flexible. Decent Profit Sharing.
cons:
Low Salary. Work here for 4 years and find out that new college graduate make as much as you do.  They try to take advantage of you as much as they can. 

Even though it's a big company growth opportunity is actually limited. They have a hiring freeze and make you do all the work with little reward.

review_title: Texas Instruments is a great place to work as long as you know what you want to do as a career.
pros:
Good opportunities for the engineering population - if specific engineering positions are of interest. 
Name recognition
Management support to gain visibility throughout the organization
Benefits are great and unmatched to other in the industry
cons:
Not as much cross training to other disciplines
Not many promotions in smaller sub-orgs of the company

review_title: A Good Place To Work - If You Have Low Expectations
pros: Brand name. Easier to access customers than smaller company.
cons: Lack of respect for lower level employees. Promotions and pay rises not linked to competence or performance. Office politics and your ability to align yourself with the right people is the only thing that will drive your career forward here. There is a significant gap between what senior management says and how strategy is implemented by the lower levels of management. By promoting based on office politics rather than ability there are some truly horrible managers.

review_title: Impressions may vary across business units but in general a combination of a healthy culture with some politics.
pros:
1) Great islands of innovation within a big company bureacracy
2) Talk about fairness is backed by more than lip-service but management is far from ideal
cons:
1) Big bureaucratic machinery is often frustrating
2) Promotions and raises (or absence thereof) are often inexplicable
3) Big-time inter-site politics between Europe and US sites

pros:
- Smart people...one is aware he/she is working with some of the best minds in industry.
- Competitive salary, given Dallas' cost of living
- Stability
cons:
- TI could be better if it reduced some of the redundancy in terms of leadership.  Too many levels of intermediate management.
- Doesn't take as many risks in terms of new ventures

pros: The best thing about TI is that most management are easily approachable. They do listen to what you are concerned about and will try to address as much as possible.
cons: A lot of engineering tasks are actually done overseas, it might be difficult to accelerate with a pure engineering background.

pros:
1) Lots of great people there, chances to learn from them and interact with the best and brightest
2) excellent benefits, good 401(k) matching, profit sharing
cons:
1) management spread is too wide. You might report to a manager who doesn't have a technical background and who only cares about the bottomline dollars.
2) exposed to the cyclical nature of the semiconductor industry, layoffs are possible.

pros: No office politics, technical/people managers very good at their job of managing, no HR interference; lot of flexibility in pursuing opportunities which interest you, be it technical or non-technical.
cons: Got unexciting after a year of working here, maybe due to slow-moving nature of semiconductor industry itself. Also, people here have been around for really long time, which means they get into a routine.

review_title: Ok place to work. Little work life balance
pros: The benefits and pay at Texas Instruments are above average but they expect every bit in return. We were expected to go in many days off for extra training.
cons: Work life balance stinks. You are expected to come in on days off many times. there is no repsect for longevity. Once you rise up the ranks to earn a nice salary they look for ways to replace you with a cheaper alternative.

review_title: Technically challenging, creatively satisfying (push for innovation) , a very open and flexible environment
pros:
1. Very open environment, knowledgeable and helpful team-mates.
2. Employees are valued a lot and are given immense freedom.
3. Opportunity to work on cutting-edge in semiconductor industry
cons:
1. Not a very aggressive company. 
2. A little ambiguity in business strategy.
3. Slightly lower compensation than the highest in the industry.

review_title: Overall a good company to work for where you can achive life work balance
job_title: Product Marketing Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros: Depending on which business unit you work for, stress level can vary, but overall it's an easy work place. Company value and culture is very solid, people are generally well treated.
cons: Compensation is not outstanding. As a big old company, it had to go through frequent reorgs to adapt to various challenges. Not every reorg was smart move. Employees may feel frustrated with the inefficiencies and overhead of a large organization.

review_title: Good colleagues. Ok work, bad management, less pay compared to other semiconductor companies in Munich area
pros: Excellent colleagues and open work culture.
cons:
Company is cash driven. As soon as they see some losses they decide to downsize.
HR department is worst. No room to negotiate.

Betriebsrat is "namesake". They work on commands from HR. So pretty useless to expect any support from them!

pros: Invests in the employees. People make the company. Great growth semiconductor company and great place to work for. Profit sharing and stock options are great benefits.
cons: Was slow to pick on smartphone mobile market. Stayed too long with Nokia older technologies instead of focusing on higher growth areas like mobile devices. Needs to be aggressive and more innovative.

pros: Great company to start your career. Be professional and assertive and your career can takeoff.  If you are lucky to get the right manager, you will do well.
cons: Ensure you take credit for your achievements no matter how small. If you don't, there is a good chance your actions  will be overlooked no matter how valuable they are to the company. Young managers are not always experienced enough to develop talent.

job_title: Account Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Within sales, there are many locations.  The program allows you to put in your preference of location, although it is not guaranteed that you will be relocated to your preferred location.  However, it is good that they allow you to express your opinion.  There are many people that are willing to help and provide mentorship.
cons: Depending on the sales office, it is very fast-paced so keeping up can be difficult.  Also, it is very difficult to keep a good work/life balance.

pros: Pay is good, Decent work life balance. Good peers
cons:
1.  PDK teams sucks, clearly don't have any idea to adjust for newer technologies. Don't take other team inputs seriously.

2. Cafeteria food is pathetic and too costly.

3. Guards are  GADAR film heroes, without ID card they will treat you like you are from Mars.

4.  Still use Microsoft Outlook 2010,don't know how much they save by not updating this.

review_title: A once great company, no more.
job_title: Member, Group Technical Staff in Dallas, TX
pros: Good pay.  Some good middle managers, some awful.
cons: Leadership has given up.  No vision.  Every technical manager has a target on is back.  They chose to leave $1.5B annually on the table when they walked away from Nokia by quitting CMOS development.  They figured out how to squeeze profit while a business unit dies.  The board is completely asleep at the wheel.

review_title: TI is a great place to work
job_title: Test Development Engineer in Dallas, TX

cons: Some organizations in TI seems to care more about talent development than others. It is obvious that the organization that is not growing (generating lots of cash) can not afford to train or development an employee if he/she desires a career change.

2. Good facilities for employees.

4. Lot of options to work in different business groups with a wide variety of products.
cons: 1. Major arch work still done out of US and France. Most of the work is execution as opposed to actually defining a product.

review_title: Good place for me, and as a company

cons: Occasionall interest in self-profiling of own team vs. (internally) competing teams, and see someone re-inventing the wheel just because no one happened to know the first solution.

pros: Broad portfolio, providing some level of access to nearly any customer base in the world.  High intensity environment, with a strong engineering community to support you.
cons: Currently developing new sales tools and metrics, which has created some gap in customer focus and inconsistency as the organization evolves the tools.

review_title: Bail out of this sinking ship while you can
job_title: Electrical Design Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros:
- Sychophant management

pros: A large company like TI affords a lot of opportunities for early career professionals. Very good mobility within the company once you have a job. Managers, in general, care about your career progress. Salary and benefits are very competitive

pros: campus is good, great building , peaceful labs and quiet environment.overall great place to work. good cafeteria and choice of food is good

review_title: Good as a Corporation but do your homework before accepting an offer

Very smart people 
multinational presence gives a chance to work with employees in different countries
Cutting edge technology work
Market leader in many products

limited advancement opportunities

pros:

review_title: It was a very fulfilling experience at TI, I was able to learn as much as I could absorb everyday.

review_title: As a new grad, the environment at TI promotes open mentorship with emphasis in conducting business eithically.

review_title: I have nothing but good things to say about Texas Instruments. It is Nerd Paradise and Geek Heaven.

pros: Professional corporate culture, great benefits, solid Fortune 500 company with a respected reputation.
cons: Can be stifling to innovation and opportunity due to top-heavy management structure. Too many middle managers that impede communication and responsiveness.

pros: great people, interesting products, always challenges, and there are always changes. There is really a diverse group of people from different nations that you get to work with. TI is a good global company.
cons: big company, and slow moving. There are tons of layers of TI and it can be frustrating to deal with all of the checks.

review_title: TI is a good place to work, however be prepared for big layoffs every few years.

Good opportunity to move around in the company.
Can grow into higher position with separate technical & management tracks.
Very family friendly company

pros:

review_title: not perfect, but I miss it
job_title: Customer Program Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: Career growth opportunities with variety in a single company is great. Didn't see the politics found elsewhere.  Culture values corporate heritage with a goal to continue to earn it.
cons: Middle level management is hit or miss.  Some great, others not.  Once you get a negative performance review from any it is hard to recover. Salary nothing to write home about, prefer to hire more expensive, less experienced from outside than pay current employees.

review_title: Tesas Instruments: a view from an retiree
pros:
Strong IDM Iintegrated Device Manufacturer) in analog IC, power IC, and embedded ICs with
good market shares with highly structured organizations and strong leadership.
cons: Too many reorganizations with constantly changing and confusing landscape.  Too much emphasis on numbers and short-term planning. Communication and coordination among different groups can be difficult.

job_title: Patent Administrator (Though They Called Us Legal Assistants) in Blue Ridge, TX
pros: Insurance was good and reasonably priced since the company has so many employees.
cons: They give you the title of 'legal assistant' when you're actually doing paralegal work; that way they can keep the pay low. Also, management is concerned with outside sales/bottom dollar, not with employees.

pros: The people at TI are top notch.  They consistently are there to help and provide support along the way.  Managers invest in their teams and create a culture that lines up with the values on the wall.  Coming to work is never a burden; it's great to work with people you like on challenging and useful work.
cons: It is a large company, so your work only affects a narrow scope of what is actually happening at TI.

review_title: TI isn't just a great place to work -- it's a great place for your career.
pros: There are many reasons. The atmosphere at TI is extremely conducive to work. Strict hours are not enforced; you have plenty of leeway to restructure your work around personal life as long as you get the job done. I enjoy excellent relationships with my peers and my managers, and I get great feedback both when I do well and when there are areas where I need improvement. TI is also fairly good at rewarding people who make significant contributions to the organization's success. Other reasons? Great job security (I've been here for well over four years and many of the people I work with are the same people I met here when I first started) and stability, great benefits (including educational assistance), an employee stock purchase program (great savings tool!), and a perfect vacation/time bank system. But above all, as an engineer TI has given me an environment where I can do what I do best and enjoy doing it. I love working here and probably wouldn't move to another company even if they paid more.
cons: There aren't many downsides, but I'll try to list a few. First there's the "cube farm" - lots and lots of cubicles. Then, being in the semiconductor industry, your career choices are somewhat limited should you choose to change jobs. A lot of what you learn to do at TI is very proprietary -- in essence, choosing a career at TI is a long-term investment. Also as a product engineer, unless you prove yourself to be innovative and stand out from the pack, you could find your work quite monotonous as you end up doing the same type of things over and over again. Working here can also be quite stressful at times, especially if you're in an organization that deals with quality. Deadlines and customer commitments could mean very long hours and tedious work for stretches. You need to be able to work well independently or you could struggle.

pros:
good ethics for such big company. TI is very dynamic even though it is a big company
very successful company
nice and knowledgeable people
a lot of customers everywhere
cons: R&D is spread out over the world. It is hence not as efficient as would be co-located engineering team. Working hours is crazy due to the time zones

review_title: It is a wonderful job but a stressful career

Great Benefits.
Competitive pay.
Shift work gives many consecutive days off.
Your job role plays a big part in production.

The demands of multiple bosses can conflict with each other.

review_title: Very good company, great benefits, but conservative with raises.

cons: They are very conservative with raises, even for the top performers.  You need to work in Dallas in order to really advance your career.

job_title: Technical Sales Representative in Wide Ford, MO
pros:
Aeesome pay great bosses
If your a driver free cars and unlimited gas
cons: None. I love it . Wonderful people working there no fighting we all like each other.  Hour lunch,  time to take off cheap insurance for family

review_title: A stable place to work at

cons: None that I can think of.   And if you work hard and are loyal, I'm sure you'll have problems trying to think of any Con for TI.

pros:

review_title: Challenging, but not always for the right reasons...
pros: Plenty of good here.  Competitive salary, great benefits, lots of different potential roles.  Exciting to drive the next generation of hardware.
cons: Middle management quagmire, good decisions often blocked by political interplay.  Many of the development models are antiquated and highly inefficient, but almost impossible to modify.

review_title: Great learning curves, lots of opportunity and awesome people to work with
pros:
- You have access to a wide array of technical resources in terms of people, lectures, documents
- Lots of opportunities to work on different things that interest you because of the breadth of the company
cons: - The company might get too big at times and standing out in the crowd might be difficult

review_title: Too much work pressure but may be good for those wanting to make quick bucks
pros: If you are willing to give more hours to meet deadlines, they will keep rewarding you until you continue doing so.
cons: Too much work pressure. You'll be kept on your toes almost always. Moreover, you'll be pitted against your co-workers and continuously compared with them.

pros: Successful company, knows how to reinvent itself, smart people.
cons: I walked a lot of 50-something-year-olds out during layoffs...averaged down by over-hiring out of college.  Current strategy of analog/catalog focus is smart, but not very interesting.

pros: Engaging and challenging work, sales promotes from within, good training program, good colleagues
cons: A lot of internal housekeeping that slows down the pace of business, success depends on account base

pros: Was great opportunity coming out of school.  Plenty of smart people.
cons: Slow steady decline with little regard for maintaining expertise/ability to compete. Very short sighted vision. Experience may vary from group to group.  A lot of layoffs, and lost a lot of great people afterwards as a result.

pros: Good learning opportunities out of college. Profit sharing has been strong. First year was great, then it turned into a nightmare.
cons:
All comments are my opinion.

Do you enjoy having to cc your manager and their manager on every email you send? How about weekly micromanaging sessions which you'll spend many hours preparing for (but always get crapped on during)? Watching your team of ~5 all quit in the last year or two?  Management which is commonly referred to as "slave drivers?" 

All this while being paid 40% under market value!? Bay Area compensation is truly awful. Don't think being new to relocate there will help - I knew someone from a rotation program who was let go within 9 months due to reorg. He shared a room with 2 other people. Seriously, compensation is low. 

What I learned is that there is a "culture of fear." All decisions are top down and all you are supposed to say is yes. This place will kill your soul and make you woefully unprepared for anywhere you actually have to be creative or think for yourself. Seems even after more than a year in a new company that some still couldn't shake all the bad habits and it hampered their ability to perform optimally (such as speaking up or coming up with ideas in a more open culture).

Management varies a lot in quality, had some great (all left within a year, smart), and some truly evil managers. Even after a whole team left over a couple of years and managers kept dropping like flies, nobody asked a single question of why that might be (terrible management).  

I do think the company is aware and the awful management is purposeful to some degree. Cheaper to get employees to quit than lay them off. Better to grind through people or only have the people who don't know work life boundaries stay around. Or so the thinking goes. 

Tech is awful, large parts of work should be automated and systematized. Management should be happy to hear large parts of the job could be done away with.  Does not work like a tech company under the hood. 

I learned the irony of Silicon Valley being named after dinosaurs like this while real tech companies push boundaries with their products, business model, operations, compensation, and culture. 

No CRM. Seriously, everything is tribal knowledge, email chains, and spreadsheets meticulously updated for many hours each week. Lots of early and late calls with Europe and Asia while still needing to be butt in seat during normal hours. Innovation = cheaper, long gone are the days of exciting new tech. 

Thanks for the depression, anxiety, and low pay, but I'll go elsewhere.

review_title: Good Place to work, but dont expect high compensation.
pros: Overall a very good brand name, good place to work, enough good people around to learn and increase your knowledge.
cons: Loosing projects and customers at a fast pace, getting into technical ladder difficult, overall promotions and pay hikes may not be good.

job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Dallas, TX
pros:
Truly interenational company
Great engineering talent
Good salary for entry to mid level of experience
Very strong teamwork and team culture
cons:
No recognition or rewards for formal business education
Quality of mid level management is pathetic
Analytical ability of sales and business staff is very poor

pros: Benefits are good. Co-workers are intelligent and hard-working. It's great to work with people who are innovative and down to earth. It's a big company that acts like a small one.
cons: The hours are long. Work / life balance is a challenge. Lots of meetings. Lots of conference calls. Lots of crises.

pros: great benefits, work can be challenging. global. overall not a bad place to work.  flexibility was great among most managers.
cons: career limited if you want to excel to FP&A, but others have found a way to make it work so it must be a matter of politics and persistence or both.

job_title: Software Systems Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros: Opportunity to work in different groups over the years.  Good variety of product markets learned.  Ability to move between hardware, software and system engineering jobs.  Profit sharing bonus has been good for a number of years.
cons: More focused concentration on chip level market exploration, less large system prototyping to explore markets.  Less team work, more individual result rewarded.  Very top performers are highly compensated, with minimal compensation for everyone else.

job_title: Applications Developer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: While I worked there, my boss was very considerate of my skills and passions and gave me projects that I would be more likely interested in. The company also puts value on having a healthy personal life, so they are very lax with having people work from home whenever they want.
cons: The age and large size of the company also makes the work atmosphere feel kind of rigid. This makes it harder to try new things

review_title: Solid company built on classic concepts
pros:
Large company
Very dynamic and diverse
Well connected
Strong history
Healthy Culture

To summarize, if you look at TI's history it should be very easy to see the kind of company it is. There is nothing hidden from you and the goals of the company are clear from the minute you walk in.
cons:
It is an older company and at times still clings to older concepts as well as large corporate mentality.

It has less of the conveniences that newer tech companies have.

review_title: The most caring "big organization" I have worked for.
pros: TI puts a lot of effort into making sure that employees feel valued and are taken care of...as much as any large, publicly held company can. As a contractor I felt little different than a direct hire. That is a rarity in any industry.
cons: Constant reorganizations make it difficult to establish efficient processes.

review_title: It is a solid company with competitive salary
pros: Flexibility in your job role to get things done
cons: Lack of individual recognition and career opportunities

pros: good  benefits (medical, dental, insurance), TI has many locations in US and abroad, one  could find different jobs inside the same company
cons:
poor engineering management, focus is not kept on innovation, 
business driven decisions,  engineers are easily replaceable,
80% or more of the managers are not engineering specialists

pros: Engineering centered company that strives to innovate and win.  Benefits package is competitive with industry standards.  Opportunity to grow/develop in a variety of roles.  Very talented employee base.
cons: Difficult to find work-life balance since the company manufactures on a global 24/7 operation.  While the company has a good profit-sharing program to compensate employees, it only does a mediocre job of rewarding high performers through it's pay-for-performance philosophy.  Results don't translate to monetary recognition.

review_title: Good HR and benefits, Engg culture a shambles
pros: Pay and benefits were above industry norm. HR was very helpful and trod lightly when we were laid off. Access to engineering and scientific resources was great.
cons: From a day to day work aspect though it was a byzantine network of fiefdoms. Teams in different geographies with overlapping charters that focused their energies on fighting each other to a draw.

pros: Texas Instruments has excellent benefits and a great work culture. If you're interested and determined to move up, there are many opportunities.
cons: Semiconductor manufacturing can be a stressful job at times. The facility operates 24/7 so it is not uncommon to get phone calls after your work day or on weekends.

pros: Can be the best place to work. When the right team is built, then the projects have a good chance of being successful.
cons:
inexperienced leadership.
The lower management tries to "sell" another roadmap project and then repeats the same failing recipe of managing the projects. This causes a high turnover rate.

pros: I worked there for one year. I liked the friendly environment, diverse work force.  The location I worked at was in Dallas.  I had very good experience with Texas Instrument.
cons: The organization is matrix management.  Sometime it take a while to figure out who is in charge and who to ask to get resources.

pros: Very good starting salary. Flexible working hours. Home office possibilities. Diverse & dynamic working environment. Generous learning opportunities in a structured and well defined working environment. Process and documentation oriented. Great starting point to learn the industry and kick off your career.
cons: Flat pyramid structure with few vertical transfers & little career development opportunities even after +5yrs. Nepotism, strong office politics, micro-managing middle management. Slow salary increases, of the range of 0.1%-5%.z

review_title: Solid, conservative company driven by engineers
pros: Good benefits, good communications with employees, no prima donnas in management; high ethical standards.
cons: Very conservative -- slow to make decisions and move forward; salaries are based on cost of living in Dallas -- so if you work in a major metropolitan area outside of Dallas your pay is likely to be less than that of your peers.  Stock option grants have been reduced in past years so as to become pretty much meaningless.

pros:
Profit  sharing and ESPP program
most of the managers are great to work for.
cons: very political and gives no importance to the amount of effort and results. Seniority is a big thing, and does not encourage new hires in this regards. The TECH Staff program is all political and not based on actual accomplishments, it's mind blowing to see the people they pass up and the people they promote, they give an extraordinary amount of leverage to minorities in TECH staff, raises, hiring etc. which is great if your a minority otherwise be prepared to get passed over (read between the lines).

review_title: Good place to work and learn
pros:
1. Good work life  balance.
2. Benefits are very good.
3. You get best opportunity to learn from all people around.
4. Compensation is also good.
5. Encourage people in all aspects.
cons:
1. Appraisal process is weired since they take feedback from the lead only. If you bad lead your life is hell. 
2. I feel compensation and also process can be made better.

pros: Texas Instruments is a good place to start a career in terms of intial experience.    Alot of very knowledgable engineers to learn from.
cons: Recent  changes at TI have disenfrachised alot of the senior engineering staff.   While in the past I would have easily recommended friends to join the team, with the current direction I now would hesitate to make such a recommendation.

review_title: Struggling hard to find its place, after wireless sale
pros: Great tech people, has good technology access. Was number 1 in wireless, had great application processor business and MCU business, now everything looks to be in disarray
cons: Poor managers and leaders, lacks vision. Change of strategic direction is not looking promising. Appears to be selecting strategy based on ease of  implementation and not on sound reasoning.

pros: There is great international support to local operations from the head quarters. The team is formed by capable ans specialist professionals, which promotes a good international synergy.  There is a good environment to work; possibility to travel and learning rotations in other countries.
cons: There is a limited head count in some locations, which limits the number of employees per office depending on a series of factors. Therefore some employees are hired through third parties.

review_title: One of the best places to work
pros:
Quality of work was very good. The work that was being done here at bangalore before TI exited the cellular business was truly world class. 

Work culture / work-life balance was valued and supported by the management.

One got to work with smart/experienced engineers from all around the world.
cons:
The compensation was below par with TI management trading off its good reputation with lower salary.

Promotions were had to come by for most.

review_title: It was a good learning experience with good opportunities to expand my technical skills.
pros: With the department I worked in, I was given the freedom to manage my own time and strategy at work but still, I can access guidance from my superiors whenever I needed it.
cons: Too much politics at the work place.

pros: Smart team, good people, dedicated employees - overall this was not a bad place at all to work. I wish the facilities were nicer, the whole place needs a severe facelift.
cons: Extremely cheap when it comes to spending money. The compensation isn't necessarily bad or unfair, but the spending on everything else is very limited. We had to chip in monthly for paper towels and plasticware in the break room.

pros: Work is shared well among all team-members. New members are not sidelined. Great work life balance. Work is of good quality in most teams. Good industry standard salary and bonuses.
cons: In some teams (my team for eg), the project given to the team as a whole did not seem important from the company point of view.

review_title: Good place to learn how a large company builds chips
pros: It's a good place to learn the basics of the semiconductor industry.  There are strong processes in place for every aspect of bringing a chip from concept to mass production.
cons: It is a very large company, and can feel like there is a process for everything. That can be helpful when doing standard products, but can become a challenge when trying to do something new or different.

review_title: Run, don't walk, away from this place- no matter how much money/stock options they throw at you
pros: Great pay (they have to in order to abuse people the way they do). Good on a resume (unless your future employer has worked there, and then they'll want to make sure you weren't there very long and that you were smart enough to see how dysfunctional it was.) Great benefits (right up until the point they outsource your job to China or India).  Summary: If you are only interested in high wages and good benefits while suffering abuse and having your skills waste away until they find away to replace you with a new-college-graduate in China or India- this is the place for you! Ran by people who know how to get the stock price up, regardless of the long-term implications for employees or their families.
cons:
We go through a big organizational shake-up every 1-2 years so you never get a chance to actually *do* anything but meet your new boss and fill out new forms. TI is run by accountants and slimy/unethical salesmen who load the ranks with terrible middle-managers which carry out their biddings in hopes that they will impress their bosses (while not giving any thought to you or your family). They fill up your traditional 40 hour work week with meetings, and checking-of-irrelevant-boxes, various United Way campaigns and diversity initiatives and then expect you to do the actual *work* in your free time. You will be treated as an untrusted invader walking around in their building- a bothersome cost sink that is there just to make sure decades old technology is delivered according to some unreasonable schedule that they have poorly planned for and staffed to meet. You will NOT do  anything innovative here- no matter how much you've drank the marketing kool-aid. The management desires only to make cheap foreign-produced products and only make something special every once in a great while when something innovative sneaks past them. They buy great american companies when they want innovation, then completely mismanage and mishandle the portfolios they inherent while trying to get as much quick and easy money from the innovation they purchased

It is a demoralizing place to work, and supremely dehumanizing in nearly every way.

pros:
Great people to work with
One of the best ethical companies: "Do the right thing"
Very understandable peers
Open Culture
Freedom of work/job rotation
Great benefits - in addition to primary compensation
Great work!
cons:
More work per person than feasible most times-- esp software development
Sometimes does not take bold technology or marketing risks

review_title: Good place to start after graduate from college
pros:
1. Relatively good salary in DFT area.
2. Have a good balance between job and life
3. Good place to learn SC.
cons:
1. HR doesn't really work
2. Managers' styles are so different, there are many managers came from Asia who have bad mentality, it becomes hard to deal with.

pros:
- There are good projects available 
- There is no micro management. Has trust in employees.
- Good work life balance and facilities.
- Good commute options
cons:
- innovation is on paper only; no real push or rewards.
- Too many changes in technologies and organisation structure. It is pretty confusing at times.
- Avg salary

review_title: An excellent first job for a young engineer
pros: Lots of smart employees to learn from, resources and benefits of a large company, steady job to pay off student loans and save money when in your youth, working in some interesting areas of the market and interacting with big and small customers, diverse workforce
cons: Old and conservative company, pay and raises could be better for younger employees, restrained by large size

review_title: Lots of potential to learn, company direction unclear.
pros: There are some great people to work with at TI.  It's has great ethics policies and behavior.  There are lots of potential areas to learn in.
cons: Lots of short-sighted off-shoring happened with people training their own replacements.

review_title: Great place to learn, but environment is changing.
pros: Competitive pay and benefits, good work life balance, great and very intelligent teams.
cons: New direction seems to be towards commodities - both in products and in people.  Lack of commitment to talent development outside of EE design teams.

review_title: Treated like crap at the end but good while it lasted
pros:
Good pay and benefits for more senior positions.
Good people at the staff level.
Good functional managers.
Small teams feels like smaller company.
cons:
Don't work for a remote design center -- first to get axed.
Total lack of cooperation across business units. 
Sales people running a technology company ... not a good idea.

pros: TI is a financially stable corporation. The company is able to keep reinventing itself making it very competitive firm in the semiconductors'  industry.
cons: There should be improvements in the Work/Life balance. There is a lot of pressure on the Manufacturing team in the fabs. The personnel in the Wafer Fabs are very productive. I believe we ask a lot more out of the few employees than what was asked in the past.

review_title: Good company, bad digital business and decisions
pros:
Good work culture 
Industry leading pay
Sense of ownership and responsibility 
Technically strong teams
Good Hr policies and people practice
cons:
Digital business not doing well and future looks bleak. But its the best for analog guys. 
2 successive big layoffs worldwide in the digital business. 
No transparency in internal job change.

pros: Good benefits, flexible hours, good perks, great training potential for training programs. However, many employees do not treat you with respect if you are in a training program.
cons: major lack of work-life balance, lots of politics involved in the positions, lack of morale within the company. It seemed like everyone was over-worked, stressed and tired

job_title: Process Engineering Technician in Dallas, TX
pros: Profit Sharing, Paid time off, Paid holidays, good working atmosphere.
cons:
Compensation isn't always fair, many of the other techs that do the same exact job make significantly more than I do.
Missed family Holidays, It is a 24/7 factory.

job_title: Principal Applications Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros: Overall a good place. light work load. No weekend work necessary. Environment is very much dependent on the job function and group.
cons: Lack of innovation and hiring of very green engineers makes look elementary in approach and execution.

review_title: It's all about who you know
job_title: Financial Planning Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros: Learn as much as you can then move on. Don't get content with your position.  Collaborate outside of your team. Volunteer at events to get your name out there.
cons: Too many cliches. If your not hanging with the most popular employees, you'll never get promoted. Must be exceptional in job duties.

review_title: Excellent place to start a career
pros: Great place to learn anything from technical skills to business development. After 3 years in a role, most managers will gladly help you transfer to a new role if you so desire. Good compensation and pay, benefits are standard. Good mix of young and old.
cons: Very heavy on metrics. Tools will roll out that aren't complete yet. Metrics then based on sub-par tools.

job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Dallas, TX
pros: It is a great work environment, highly collaborative, good work/life balance, reasonable compensation, challenging topics to work on, cutting edge technology.
cons: Growth opportunities are limited, maturing industry, so focus is shifting from technology to financial aspects of the business. Talent grooming could use improvement.

review_title: challenging software development in a very positive work environment
pros:
challenging work
good hr policies that take care of performing individuals
reasonably good pay
good work culture
nice health club
flexible work hours
cons:
office located in CV raman nagar, making the commute to work a killer
if you are a software engineer interested in desktop, not much to do here

review_title: Been a great place to work, but may be time to move on when economy improves.
pros: Have had opportunities to work in many different groups, with great opportunities to expand my base of knowledge in areas like Engineering, Marketing, Operations, and Finance
cons: Your supervisor is typically not actively trying to promote you as much as themselves. You definitely have to have a strong network in order to continue to move into more challenging and exciting roles.

pros: good place to learn basics, high ethical standards, less politics, very bright minds at work, flexi timing, no nonsense of being inside office for stipulated amount of time
cons: growth oppurtunity is very less, always less than average salary as compared to the other IC design companies, a company which does not grow aggressively and does not take any risks on any vector

pros: Good in working environment and benefit wise, even with a sports complex.
cons:
Demanding (certain Dept.) that causes stress.
High expectations, strict managers and loads of task that employees hardly utilize the sports complex.
Hardly achive balance between work and life, some employees even stay in the office/plants for more than 12 hours.

pros:
state of the art technologies, fair compensation package, excellent working place and facilities, opportunity to evolve in a truly international environment (both TI sites over the world and international customers)
Expat packages are really generous
cons:
- difficult to move internally or be relocated to other TI sites abroad
- too heavy management, slow decision process
- lack of visibility on the global strategy, little room for initiatives

pros: the working place is clean room with a humble and good training,a computerized work  process,  nice to be part of big technology, worked as an manufacturing operator for a couple of years
cons: what they make and what they pay you is incomparable,  working 12 hours a day for lessthan 10 dollar per hr..max about 13?

job_title: Technical Sales Associate in Dallas, TX
pros: It has a really great training program, probably the best in the industry. Learned a lot, got great mentors.
cons: While there is great training, a lot of it is also on yourself to go out there and be aggressive in pursuing sales calls and bonding with other employees already at the company.

review_title: Old school management, top notch engineering
pros:
Texas Instruments has a wealth of cutting edge engineering. Management is old school, but they are neither afraid to explore new opportunities with serious money - nor are they shy about cutting loses when opportunity ends.

The engineering team I worked with at TI was the MOST diverse of my entire career - ethnically, gender, international, poly-lingual. Eye opening and exciting!
cons: Compensation is good, but not outstanding.

pros: Healthy diversity is supported at TI. There is no bias based on religion, race, sexual orientation, nationality, etc. TI's comprehensive diversity network allows employees to participate in many different employee-run diversity groups. TI as a whole seems to stand behind good values and treats their employees well.
cons: Opportunities for promotion seem limited based on management and tech ladder structures. I get the sense that promotions and raises move slower than other companies.

review_title: Good company to learn about technical stuff... but you have to get out to grow.
pros: Good knowledge sharing, good technical environment, good relationship with peers.
cons:
Promotion opportunities extremely limited. Opportunities to young engineers almost non-existant.
Amazingly a company with this much brain power promotes managers based on seniority and not performance nor knowledge. Promotion criteria completely wrong.

pros:
- Opportunities for growth
- Career transitions from a role to another within the company possible
- Good pay
-
cons:
- Don't approve of the leadership decisions at this point
- Radical changes in company performance from quarter to quarter
- Not much control on what you want to work on

pros:
Salary, 
Work Life Balance, Onsite,
Prestiguous. Technology & Thought Leadership.
Large Organization means potential to meet soo many interesting, smart people.
cons: Join no later than October or November, or else you'll likely won't be 'rated' for promotion the next year. You'll run the risk of working the whole year for "FREE", with none of that work counting towards promotion. I you join after that time, try to come in at the next level above.

review_title: it's been good, but things are changing fast, and not necessarily for the better.
pros: There are many good hard working people at this company.
cons: Management is becoming oppressive.  Layers of management are being added, and promotions go to young fresh engineers/marketing people who do not have the training, ability, or often the aptitude to manage people or projects.

review_title: An excellent company for career opportunities, professionnal satisfaction and work-life balance
pros:
- amazing site with seaview, tennis courts, volley-ball and football pitches.
- good salary for this location (Sophia Antipolis is usually -20% vs. Paris).
- young and dynamic culture
- quite flexible to switch jobs when opportunities are available.
cons:
- big big company
- might be too much process oriented, so a lot of reuse and not so much true innovation (if you are an engineer)

review_title: Good pay and benefits, but getting off nights is difficult.
pros: It is a well-paying job for an hourly position.  Most fellow employees are good to work with.  The benefits are good in comparison to other companies.
cons: It can be very hard to get off of nights.  Revolving door managers are disconnected to staff because they don't expect to be in the position more than two years.

review_title: I worked hard and learned from brilliant people.
pros: Texas Instruments owns fabs and thus, is likely to be around for a long time. The people who work here are smart.
cons: They have a tendency to abandon ship when they aren't the best solution in the market place, meaning if your product isn't growing faster than the competition they will just lay you off rather than try and solve the underlying problem.

review_title: the inmates were running the asylum
pros: recreation center  salary benefits commute
cons:
the security controls and officers are a little more intrusive than necessary one technician read all emails and management knew so they avoided emails
employees call pretended to be headhunters to try and discover your salary and then it travels quickly
my relocation realtor told someone of all the neighborhoods I looked at and it travelled through the building

review_title: A very dinamic and fast moving company.
pros: Salary level is above average. You can learn a lot about discipline and processes. Easy to sell products, good portfolio.
cons: Fluctuation is high. The Board spends too much time on reviewing the field puting extremely high pressure on managers, therefore people are escaping the company. The relatively high fluctuation in every level combined with having no CRM system causes loss of valuable knowledge and relationship.

review_title: Good experience, but TI does not like to give comparable raises.
pros: The best reason to work here is it's a good place to start and get experience & training.  Good employee stock option programs.
cons: The challenges of working is the management has a blase "stay or go" attitude towards employees.  The pay lacks behind industry standards.

job_title: Wafer Fab Technician in Dallas, TX
pros: 3-4 days a week, decent vacation time, veteran friendly, lots of prior military techs and management, has a technical ladder that you can move up, 15% night shift bonus
cons: 12 hour days plus the drive to and from, possible mandatory night shift

pros:
Worldwide opportunities
Some great coworkers
Very competitive compensation
Accessible leadership
Interesting challenges
cons:
It's a big company so things can be slow to change
Very bureaucratic at times, including with fairly rigid pay/benefit structures
Training and onboarding process is long and painful
Lots of managers
Sometimes the work/life balance swings too far towards work, especially in manufacturing roles

pros:
Great place to start your career, Texas Instruments offers so much career growth opportunities.
Profit Share. 13th and 14th month pay.
cons: There is nothing bad about this company that i could think of. It has got to be one of the best companies out there.

job_title: Product Marketing Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Some co-workers are smart and can learn from them
Company is doing well financially.
cons:
Very political
Compensation is well below market
High turnover
Heavy workload and no work-life balance
Attrition, layoffs, people are let go, heavy burden to employees that stay.
Mostly terrible management and people in leadership roles who only care about their own goals and not the employees' career. Lot of managers should not be working with people, they are in strictly for the money.

review_title: Good place to start out. You will plateau quickly though, unless you take up a managerial role
pros: Cutting edge work, still a very technical company.
cons: Management entrenched and not in touch anymore. Too many managers not pulling their weight.

review_title: Time for Rich Templeton to leave. His performance is directly tied to the company's STOCK performance.
pros: Good working environment and friendly co-workers
cons: Good old boy network. It is not what you know, but who knows you makes big difference as to how one can excel in the company

pros:
Good work life balance
Great reputation in the industry
Many opportunities to move laterally within the company to different roles
cons: System for feedback and promotions is flawed and heavily rewards office politics.  Messages from upper management do not always reflect reality or follow through.

pros: I joined as an engineer from college and i had lots of opportunities to explore and need time to utilize those opprtnities thats all
cons: you should fight aggressively to get what u want and also very focussed on one particular domain for many years doesnt help much

pros:
- Employees generally show a good work attitude each other
- Cafeteria is subsidised and offers good value for money
- Off-site meetings are a nice perk
cons:
- Expensive to rent or buy local property. Need to live further away from Freising to see a drop in prices
- No ESPP due to EU regulations

review_title: not a bad place to work
pros: diversified products. financial strength. good health care plan. flexible time. co-workers are generally knowledgeable and nice to work with. lots of learning opportunities from smart knowledgeable people. managements understand the know-how, allowing them to make reasonable demands.
cons: long hours. but i guess it is the same everywhere else. every companies try to get the most of their employees. it's a economy wide problem.

pros:
Solid corporation.
Systems in place to manage people, products, service.
Decent benefits.
cons: Window dress with the systems in place for employee care.  Grass roots of managing employees is connecting and engaging with the employee, and I don't see this at all by mid to upper management.  This practice most definitely funnels to line supervisors in the way they manage their lines/people.

review_title: Great place to learn and grow
pros: TI offers so many different opportunities in one place, lots of flexibility to try new roles and take on different challenges.  Great colleagues who always want to help, very open discussions.  High standard of ethics.
cons: It's a big company, so things can sometimes move slowly.  You need to be persistent to make things happen here.  Leaders can sometimes be too customer focused.

pros: There was a very good motivation from everyone on the team. The works hours were also pretty much flexible. Feedback was provided then and there.
cons: Sometimes the work might get too demanding, forcing you to stay up late into the night. Other than this, I could not think of any other con .

review_title: Great atmosphere at a top company!
job_title: Applications Software Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros: Great talent.  Good pay and benefits.  Excellent work/life balance.  Top notch management.
cons: Something is missing to keep this company from truly breaking out and winning the market share that is desired.  I wouldn't expect the company to experience huge growth, but it is has terrific financials.  Not afraid to reorganize and cut jobs in the process.

review_title: Good Place to cut your teeth...
pros: Excellent training program for student hires, promotional opportunities in early years, competitive pay, opportunities for meaty jobs very quickly
cons: No real value placed on experience, promotions based on potential as opposed to actual results

review_title: Mediocre at best…the grass is definitely greener
pros:
+High salaries relative to market

+Flexible work arrangements (but only if your manager supports this or likes you…many managers will say no, or guilt trip you if you work from home with no reason).  Flexibility is only a benefit if it's consistently applied for everyone, not just those employees with children.

+Great experience for early career folks (stretch roles with a lot of responsibility)

+Large amount of new college grads starting every year, easy to build up a great group of friends if you're a transplant to Dallas

+Opportunities to work in international locations

+Relatively flat org structure
cons:
-If you work here, expect to work 24/7.  Work/life balance is virtually nonexistent.  I work at another company now, and I have never been happier.  TI was my first job out of college, so I thought this was normal.  It's not!  Don't be scared of trying something new if you're not happy.

-"Old boys club" culture.  Comms and HR are trying hard to turn it around and offer fun activities like Jack Kilby Day, but as long as the company is full of disgruntled people, the culture will definitely not be turning around anytime soon.  

-Lack of transparency around processes/procedures, especially compensation cycle, leads to employees distrusting HR

-Forced distribution rankings for performance = getting zeroed out for yearly raises, even when there is not a known performance concern.  Very bad for morale/engagement!  Especially in suffering business units.

pros: Broad range of electronics component offerings offer stable future. Changing positions within company is promoted which offers a diverse work experience, personal growth and job satisfaction. Excellent communication of company strategy and how each employee contributes to success.
cons: A small percentage of managers and supervisors practice bullying which taints some employee, supplier & customer experiences.

review_title: Conservative company moving in the right direction
job_title: Product Marketing Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros: Diversified portfolio of broad market devices selling to a variety of customers in multiple industries at respectable margins.
cons: Company can be slow to act and conservative in its thinking. Avoiding risks is very important, it is a "safe" company.

pros: Very good for out of school new Hires, Starting salary is excellent
cons: Since starting salary is good, raise is poor.  since Texas instrument the only major semiconductor company in Dallas area, the pay raises for 6+ years experience is POOR.  internal transfer are difficult, hence feeling of suffocation and hitting a plateau is common for 6+ years of experience folks also because company does not invest in development.

review_title: Great co workers and great mentor
pros:
Great training program that lasts about one month, including technical training and project management. 
Co workers are very nice. Team building every month.
cons: Expect for that I have to pay for my housing. But it is worthwhile the learning opportunity and build your network in the indistry.

job_title: Software Engineer in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: Great work environment and plenty of learning opportunities. Bonuses are good if you are a TIer.
cons: Lack of growth opportunities and laid offs are arbitrary. It  does not count how well you performed overall, it only counts that the TI'ers headcount matches with the numbers expected by the investors.

pros:
Good compensation
Flexible work schedule
Casual environment
cons:
Mobility is limited. Very hard to change job roles outside of current org.
Fab manager rotates out every 2 years or so.
No formal training. Sink or swim environment.

job_title: Senior Test Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Decent campus, a fraction of co-workers are extremely talented individuals
cons: Bad management that does not care about employees, only measures employees by ROI. Treat employees like robots and cost centers. Age discrimination, compensation is not the best, work life balance is very bad, high turnover which results in higher stress and work for employees that stay. Little opportunities for advancement. Managers with bad social skills, they might have been good engineers but, do not know how to manage people.

pros: Great place to learn, very exciting time to be a part of the company. Ethical working environment, great benefits, friendly people.
cons: As with any other company in this position, it was stressful to go thru outsourcing process when decided to move their manufacturing facilities out of US.

pros: Might be OK for someone fresh out of college who does not know any better.
cons: The women in charge of TI Corporate Communications are only concerned about making a name for themselves, at the expense of everyone around them. They have created a truly toxic environment and pushed many talented people out.

pros: Some innovative and motivated employees who are dedicated to making TI an industry leader.  The information sharing among peers is great and encourages out of the box thinking.
cons: Many "freeloaders" who surf the internet all day.  Management does a poor job at improving their performance and/or "weeding" them out.

review_title: Good company to start your Career

1. Large organization. Plenty of opportunities
2. Broad spectrum of semiconductor products
3. Relatively stable among semiconductor companies. good place for a long career.

1. Very traditional management style.
2. Not a particularly high energy place. Can get frustarting if you are a go-getter.

- Ethics Dept

- Large variation in experience depending on dept. or supervisor.
- Some Jobs seen to have "set asides" to fill them
- Women seem to be current initiative to be promoted for gender rather than performance.

cons:
Not dynamic enough. Force organized vacations. 
Follows after market leaders. If decides the niche is big enough for another player, enters the market. Barely competes against aggressive market players. Connectivity division has lost direction and tries to reinvent itself.

pros: Diversity of the workforce and the diversity of assignments that you could work on were very broad.
cons: It tends to be very internally focused, not as open to outside ideas and inputs and might be beneficial.

review_title: Was acquired in the National Semiconductor purchase
